paragraphs.text: I got rid of the hidden menu altogether and replaced it with easy-access/quick buttons. Users could now also save/exit or undo/redo easily with the quick access buttons.
paragraphs.name: 6dee

e54b00195db1.title: Yeah that was one problem I struggled with- In my prototype, you could see that the photo is…

paragraphs.text: Yeah that was one problem I struggled with- In my prototype, you could see that the photo is clickable which would lead to a full size zoom to see finer details! It’s not the best solution, so I will try to explore this problem more.
paragraphs.name: 31c1

paragraphs.text: Thank you Naush!
paragraphs.name: 2e95

paragraphs.text: That’s super nice Kevin. About the share button, I guess VSCO keeps on this way to encourage the use of VSCO network. I mean it’s the same when you’re taking a photo using the Instagram app and those photo filters and then would like to save the photo or share using another social media. Definitely isn’t easy.
paragraphs.name: ce07

9803f8df3ef4.title: Just downloaded VSCO a few days ago on a recommendation and got very confused.

paragraphs.text: Just downloaded VSCO a few days ago on a recommendation and got very confused. Decided I might use the (excellent) film filters but forgot about it. Then you walked us through the proposed redesign — very nice article.
paragraphs.name: 5ec2

62450bf2fb97.title: Excellent diagnosis of the problems with VSCO and brilliant prognosis of the plan of action.

paragraphs.text: Excellent diagnosis of the problems with VSCO and brilliant prognosis of the plan of action.
The message from the article is loud and clear, Make things as simple as possible, but not simpler.
paragraphs.name: a473

virtuals.subtitle: The message from the article is loud and clear, Make things as simple as possible, but not simpler.

content.subtitle: The message from the article is loud and clear, Make things as simple as possible, but not simpler.

paragraphs.text: Nice work. I read the comments with great interest, to the effect that obscurity is a conscious decision by the VSCO creators. I’ve read studies about how only 16% of people who downloaded an app will give it a third try if they found it hard to use. 80–90% of downloaded apps are used once and then abandoned.
paragraphs.name: b748

virtuals.subtitle: So it seems a conscious decision to make an app obscure to use, to appeal to “hipsters” might also be a decision to limit the market for…

content.subtitle: So it seems a conscious decision to make an app obscure to use, to appeal to “hipsters” might also be a decision to limit the market for…

f07fa5c3e6d2.title: As a huge fan of VSCO and an old user, I can tell you that even I usually miss and select the wrong…

paragraphs.text: As a huge fan of VSCO and an old user, I can tell you that even I usually miss and select the wrong menu item. Your advice is really nice and meaningful. Thanks for sharing.
paragraphs.name: 0f3b

c74e7ceb4a01.title: Thank you for the awesome feedback!

paragraphs.text: Thank you for the awesome feedback! I am aware that VSCO’s design choices are intentional, but I just wanted to play around with the design to see if I could help balance bringing in new users while not alienating current power users like yourself.

virtuals.subtitle: I did not know you could reorder filters! I wonder what else is in the app that I am unaware of…

content.subtitle: I did not know you could reorder filters! I wonder what else is in the app that I am unaware of…

a18e7d4ae440.title: It took me a very long time to figure this app out — I still get annoyed by the lack of labels and…

paragraphs.text: It took me a very long time to figure this app out — I still get annoyed by the lack of labels and the sharing pain points you’ve mentioned. I edit all my photos on VSCO. I’ve never taken a photo directly from VSCO, I didn’t know these features existed! Thank you!
I love this. A lot. As a long time user of VSCO the nature of the app’s UX has been engrained in my brain, but can DEFINITELY see how this would scare away new users.
paragraphs.name: 826f

paragraphs.text: I’ve always wanted to do UX redesigns like this, and you crushed this out of the park. Nicely done

8f3251e9b3f8.title: Wow! The PPP us most impressed.

paragraphs.text: Wow! The PPP us most impressed. I use VSCO for editing but the interface does suck. And until I read your article, I did not know there was a camera function! Get the app owners to take up your redesign.
Same here. I use VSCO for filters ONLY. All other edits I make in different apps. Their current app has one of the worst interfaces I’ve ever seen.
paragraphs.name: ee58

paragraphs.text: thanks for your sharing~
Great work Kevin 🙌🏼

paragraphs.text: Interesting exercise! Given that it sounds like your testing was simple and quick, I’d be interested to hear the results of the same tests for people that aren’t new to VSCO.

paragraphs.text: I am a veteran VSCO user, and I admit my experience with the app at first was wonky, but as soon as I transcended beyond the learning curve, using the…

paragraphs.text: Cool redesign. I like your systematic approach and testing with real users. That said I feel like you kind of miss the point of VSCO. Part of its appeal is the hard-to-use-hipster-exclusive vibe that the app does so well. Making the app more useable would be against its fundamental design philosophy. Similar to Snapchat I genuinely believe that some…
paragraphs.name: 7a22
